body:
Hi Parisa,

in fact these are weighting functions derived from v(lamda). So you
should use them only when  all your quantities are in photometric units.
Irradiance "usually" implies the solar spectrum, but in RADIANCE this
is  used also only considering the visible spectrum (and then using the
weighting). I'm not sure if a color weighting makes sense when talking
about radiometric quantities using the solar spectrum. Usually I
calculate everything in "grey" (r=g=b) when using the radiometric
quantities, so this problem doesn't occur. Be aware, that you usually
calculate everything in photometric quantities in RADIANCE, so if you
want to calculate the solar spectral behavior you have to take care of
using the related values(solar transmittance for glazing, solar
reflectance of surfaces and generate sky and sun with radiometric
quantities). As far as I know only if you use gendaylit with the -O 1
option, then sky and sun are automatically in radiometric quantities
(which means your results are in W/m*m solar spectrum).

Jan
